Although the probability of identifying a correct note is always .17, the probability of identifying a correct note twice in a row is .0289 and the probability of identifying a note three times in a row is .004913. Use a two sample mean t-test.  /  / First, check conditions: / -independence between groups and within each group / -randomization / -n<10% of population / -n1p1 >/= 10, n1q1 >/= 10, n2p2 >/= 10, n2q2 >/= 10 /  / Null Hypothesis : Average length of fish caught by Mark - Average length of fish caught by Dan = 0 / Alternative Hypothesis : Average length of fish caught by Mark - Average length of fish caught by Dan is greater than 0 /  / Find standard error: / (standard deviation of Mark's fish squared over number of fish caught by mark) + (standard deviation of Dan's fish squared over number of fish caught by Dan) and take the square root. /  / On a graphing calculator : / stats -> tests -> 2-sampTTest -> plug in the values for mean length of fish for each brother, standard deviation of fish caught by each brother, and number of fish caught by each brother -> use the greater than function -> not pooled /  / It will give you a p-value. Use alpha = 0.05 to determine significance. If p-value is less than 0.05, then mark catches statistically significantly larger fish than mark does. If not, then run the test again with Dan > Mark as the alternate hypothesis this time. If the p-value is less than 0.05 then Dan catches statistically significantly larger fish than Mark. if not, then there is no statistical difference between the length of fish caught by the two brothers, therefore one is not a better fisher than the other
Yes, statistical inference should be used if the brothers consider the better fisherman to be the one who catches larger fish.

Statistical inference is not needed to figure out whether or not to reject the bulk order. Since the cutoff value is 5%, we simply need to figure out if 5% of the screens were determined to be bad by the engineer. To do this, multiply 150 by 0.05. This gives us 7.5. So, if more than 7 of the screens are bad, reject the order, otherwise keep it.
No, statistic inference is not needed.

For the sake of this problem, we will assume that all conditions have been met and the criteria for a person with a "good ear for music" is able to correctly identify music notes more than 90% of the time. /  / Null Hypothesis: Carla cannot correctly identify music notes 90% of the time / Alternate Hypothesis: Carla can correctly identify music notes 90% of the time /  / Use the proportion of times Carla is able to correctly identify the music notes as the proportion mean and find the standard error. Do this by multiplying p times q over the number of times Carla was asked to identify a note and take the square root. /  / To find the test statistic, subtract .90 (good ear) from the proportion that Carla can correctly identify the note all over the standard error that we found earlier. /  / On a graphic calculator, 2nd -> VARS -> normalcdf -> plug in (test statistic, 100) /  / If the p-value is less than 0.05 (alpha = 0.05) then the result was significant, if it is greater than 0.05 then the result was not significant. If it is significant, Carla has a good ear, otherwise she does not.

Determine an average length of a Walleye and set that equal to the null hypothesis. Set the hypothesis as larger than the average. Calculate a test statistic, and enter it into tcdf to determine the p-value. Compare this p-value to a given alpha value to determine whether to reject or fail to reject the null. reject the null if the p-value is smaller than alpha. fail to reject the null if the p-value is larger than alpha. If the null is rejected, there is signicant evidence that the fish being caught by that person are larger than average.

The null hypothesis should be set equal to 0.05 and the hypothesis should be greater than 0.05. Next, the test statistic should be determined. Use this value in tcdf to determine the p-value. Compare the p-value to a given alpha value. If it is less than alpha, reject the null hypothesis. There is significant evidence that there is more than 5% bad display screens. if it is greater than alpha, fail to reject the null hypothesis. To decide whether the student has a good ear for music, you can pick a value that represents an average ear for music. Set this average value as the null hypothesis. Make the hypothesis greater than this value, so that you are looking for a value greater than the average. Determine the test statistic by subtracting the mean from zero from the mean and divide that value by the standard error. plug this value into tcdf to determine the p-value. compare this p-value with your given alpha value to determine whether to reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis.

You could do something along the lines of a hypothesis test. You could say the null hypothesis was that p= 0.05, or that 5% of the screens were going to be bad. You're alternative hypothesis could be that the p <0.05 or that less than 5% of the screens were going to be bad in the sample of 150. Then you could carry out your hypothesis test by following the correct order of steps which are: checking the 3 conditions to make sure it will follow a normal model, see if the sampling distribution assuming the null hypothesis is true, calculating the test statistic, finding the p-value via standardizing with a z-score, and making your decision based on the p-value and finally coming to a conclusion of whether or not to reject or fail to reject your original null hypothesis.

Yes, you could use statistical inference in this case. A two means t test can be used to determine whether one brother caught bigger salmon than the other. The null hypothesis is that the mean of the brothers' salmon lengths are equal and the alternate could be that Mark's is bigger than Dan's. Check assumptions and conditions. Find the standard error and test statistic to calculate the p value. A p value bigger than the alpha level (either .01 or .05) would fail to reject the null hypothesis that they are equal. A p value smaller than the alpha level would reject the null hypothesis and give evidence that Mark's fish, on average, were bigger than Dan's.

I would determine who is the better fisherman by taking paired data. This way their differences can be accounted for. I would do this by grouping their data by Mark-Dan, this will follow through through the end of the test. The null hypothesis would be Mark-Dan = 0. And the alternate hypothesis would be Mark-Dan is less than 0. I would check the assumptions/conditions (paired, independence, randomization, small sample, normality). I would then find the p-value using the t test statisic by calculating tcdf( -100, t.s., df). The test statistics is found through the brothers differences of means and SE. If the p-value is calculated and it is small I would reject the null hypothesis showing that Mark and Dan are not equally better fisherman. I would then find the confidence interval by taking the sample pt estimate +/- (CV)(SE) and using this if the interval was negative it should show sufficient evidence that Dan is a better fisherman than Mark and if it were a positive interval Mark would be a better fisherman than dan.
Yes. It should because this data can be paired because they are brothers and have similar equipment.

First find what 5% of 150 is. / 150x.05=7.5 / So now you test the hypothesis that more than 7.5 of the screens are bad. If they are, than the order will be rejected.  / H0: damaged screens = 7.5 / HA: damaged screens > 7.5 / If the p-value is greater than 0.05 (usually), than you do not reject the null hypothesis and the order will not be rejected. But if the p-value is less than 0.05, you must reject the null hypothesis which means the order will also be rejected.

This is another 2-mean paired t test. The null hypothesis is that the average difference in fish size = 0, the alternate hypothesis is that the average difference in fish size is not equal to 0. Multiply the output by two to account for the two tailed nature of the test, unless there is a proposition that one of the two brothers is a better fisher than the other. Reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis see if there is a statistical difference between the sizes of the fish caught by the two fishermen.

Use a one proportion z-test to see if Carla has a "good ear for music." Make the null hypothesis that Carla identifies 0.5% (half) of the notes and the alternative hypothesis that she identifies more than half of the notes. Find a test statistic by dividing the proportion of notes correctly identified by the standard error. Find a p-value with the normcdf(t.s., 100) function on the calculator. Reject the null hypothesis if the p value is less than 0.9, fail to reject it if it is larger.

One can perform a t-test and then determine the p-value of the data. this p-value will tell us if it is above or below 5% , and will tell us to accept or reject the null hypothesis. The student is tested for a good ear for music by turning away from the piano as a teacher played one of seven selected notes. First off, the means that the student has no means of seeing the piano keys and the teachers fingers and where they may be on the piano. Since the student cannot see any of this, they must hear the note and go through a process within their brain to figure out which note it sounds most familiar to, then give this educated answer. If the student ahs a good ear for music, they would be able to quickly and correctly place the heard note to a note they have either played before or correctly identified before the test. If the student does not have a good ear for music, they would have no prior knowledge to correctly pair the played note with one in their memory, therefore not being able to give an educated answer.

I would decide if the student has a good ear for music by creating a simple random experiment. First step in making this experiment, is the take away anything that could flaw the experiment. The way the experiment will work is both the student and the teacher will remain in separate rooms but there will be speakers connecting the sounds from the rooms. The teacher will play notes at random and each time the student has to guess which one it is. A chaperone in each of the rooms keeping track of the notes the teacher plays and the notes the students guesses right or wrong. One-Way Anova F-test /  / 1  checking / (i) Are the observations categorized by one factor only? / NO: The observations are not categorized by one factor only so the One-way Anova F-test is not the best first analysis to do. / YES: The observations are categorized by factor only so we will now check the sample variances. / (ii) Is largest sample variance  4 ? / smallest sample variance / NO: The ratio of the largest to the smallest sample variance is greater than four so it is not safe to assume that population variances are approx equal, and the One-way Anova F-test will not be appropriate for these data. / YES: The ratio of the largest to the smallest sample variance is less-than-or- equal-to-four so it is safe to assume that the population variances are approx equal, and the One-Way Anova F-test will be appropriate. /  / 2  assumptions /  / We assume that the samples of subjects are independent SRSs and we assume that the population distributions of observations are approx Normal. /  / 3  null hyp. / H0 : Words suggesting that the population means are all the same, expressed in context. / 4  alt. hyp. /  / Ha : Words suggesting that the population means are not all the same, expressed in context. /  / 5  P-value picture / Draw an appropriately labeled density curve with the P-value shaded in. / F-crit in the output is the critical value, it is the cutoff point for the significance level entered in the Anova tool. We will not need it in this class. /  / 6  final conclusion in words, in context /  / Low P-value / The low P-value tells us that it is very likely that population mean observations are not all the same. Or words to that effect. Not-very-low P-value / The P-value is not very low so it is not unlikely that the population mean observations could be the same. Or words to that effect.

We could determine whether Mark or Dan is a better Walleye fisherman by using data collected from the fishing trip.  /  / The fish each brother catches should be collected and brought back to shore for evaluation,and measured by someone else. The brothers are more prone to bias and could easily lie about the length of the fish they caught. The person measuring should write down the total number of fish each brother caught, and then the length of each fish. Next, they should total up the lengths and divide by the total number of fish caught in order to determine the average length of fish caught for each brother.  /  Whichever brother catches the larger length average of fish is the better Walleye Fisherman.  /  / Example: Mark catches four fish that are: 4,6,8, and 10 inches in length.  /                 Dan catches four fish that are: 5,7,8, and 9 inches in length.  /  / Mark: 4+6+8+10= 28/4= 7 inches / Dan: 5+7+8+9= 29/4= 7.25 inches.  /  /  In this scenario, Dan would be the better Walleye fisherman.

Probability can be defined as the fraction of what we want to occur (desired outcomes) in the context of every possible outcome. For example, the number of event A/ Total number of events. In this case, we'll label Carla's ability to guess the notes correctly as Event A.  /  / There are 7 total notes that Carla could guess: A, B, C, D, E, F, and G.  / Carla has a 1 in 7 chances of being correct or 1/7= about 14%  /  / However, we must keep in mind that she has musical training.  / She may be able to determine by the pitch whether it would be better to guess at a lower note such as A, B, C, or even D.  / Or a higher note such as D, E, F, G.  /  / We would determine whether Carla has a good ear for music by tallying up how many times she guesses a note correctly and calculating this Event A/ the total number of events (or times she is made to guess). If she scores a 50% or higher, I would say that she does indeed have a good ear for music. If lower than 50%, it is questionable as to whether Carla has a good ear for music.  /

First, you would find p-hat. This would be how many notes guessed correctly out of all of the notes played. To find the odds, you take p-hat divided by 1 - p-hat and compare this value to 1. If the odds are equal to one, then the chance of failure is equal to the chance of success.

Like explained before, this is a classic null hypothesis/alternative hypothesis looking at proportions. The null hypothesis means that the screens are less than 5% defective. The alternative hypothesis would mean that the screens are more than 5% defective. This can be found by using a p value and calculate/looking at the z score to decide what the chance is.

You should use a statistical inference in this situation to look at binomial distributions. In this case, inference of proportions should be used.  After determing the hypothesis and null hypothesis, and determining if all of the conditions for inference are covered (if the data is an SRS and is normally distributed), one should determine the z test statistic.  Because proportions are being analyzed, one should use the p and p-hat values to determine the z statistic. After determining the z-score, the value should be compared to the critical z value.  If the determined z score is less than the critical z score, then you fail to reject the null hpothesis.

Yes, statisical inference should be used to determine whether the company should accept or reject the bulk order of display screens using the data gathered by the trained engineer because the data needs to be compared to the populations data on bulk ordering in order to draw a conclusion.

Depending on where Carla's score falls on the distribution of other scores of people who correctly identify the notes, will determine if she has a "good ear for music". Using the mean value of correct notes from the population, Carla's number of correct guesses, and the population standard deviation, the z-score can be caluclated.  From the z-score, one can determine Carla's association to all other scores on the distribution curve.  If Carla's z-score is greater than the average score of correct guesses, then she most likely has a "good ear for music".  The confidence of this score can be tested using the confidence interval formula.

Yes, statistical inference should be used to determine whether Carla has a "good ear for music".  Because Carla is a sample taken from a large population, statistical inference should be used in order to draw a conclusion about her results.

To determine whether Mark or Dan is a better Walleye fisherman, it would be necessary to add up all the lengths and weights of the Walleyes caught by each brother. Then, the average length and weight needs to be calculated and the means from both brothers should be compared to each other. If one continuously catches bigger fish at spots where the other brother catches smaller sized fish, it might be concluded that one brother is better than the other at fishing. However, as there are very many confounding factors in the data, this could only lead to correlation but not causation.

The electronics company should perform a hypothesis test for the data gathered by the engineer. The null hypothesis would be that 5% or less than 5% of the display screens are bad and the alternative hypothesis would be that more than 5% of the display screens are bad. After performing the hypothesis test, it can be concluded based on the p-value obtained, whether the null hypothesis can be rejected or is failed to be rejected.

Statistical inference should be used in this scenario because it can save a lot of time for the engineer to infer from the 5% he checked whether the rest of the display screens are fine or not, than actually checking each display screen by itself.

I would determine whether Mark or Dan is a better Walleye fisherman strictly using the confines of the data from the fishing trip calculating which person caught, on average, the larger Walleye fish in terms of fish length. To do this, I would calculate the average overall length of the total Walleye fish that each person caught by first adding up the recorded lengths of the fish that each person caught individually; as in, add the lengths of the fish that Mark caught together, and add the lengths of the fish that Dan caught together to get an over sum for fish length for both Mark and Dan. After this, I would then divide the overall fish length value for Mark by the number of fish that Mark caught, and then divide the overall fish length value for Dan by the number of fish that Dan had caught. Upon completing this calculation and finding the overall average fish lengths for each of the two fishermen, I would then compare the two averages together, and determine who was the better fisherman in context of fish length by observing who had the larger average value.

In order to decide whether the electronics company should accept or reject the order of display screens using the data gathered by the trained engineer, I would perform a one sample confidence interval using a z procedure to determine this; however since no mean is given within the scenario, it is not possible to figure out whether or not the electronics company should accept or reject the order of display screens. However, another possible way that I could figure out whether the company should accept the order or not is to determine how many of the monitors are actually working out of the 150 through reading the trained engineers data. If the data provided told me exactly how many of the 150 display screens were properly operating, then would divide the number of properly working display screens by 150; and if the percent value computed is greater than 5%, then I would advise the company to return and reject the order, and if the value is smaller than 5% then the company should accept the order of display screens.

To investigate this you need a two sample t-test. /  / First you need to plot a boxplot for both fishers of average fish length to determine the mean and check the assumptions. After we checked the assumptions we can use the difference in means of the two data samples to produce the standard errors and the 95% CI. With this CI we can see whether the difference in means is statistically significant at a 5% level

To make this a fair competition the brothers would have to have similar boats and similar equipment. The data from each brother should be kept separate so the average weight of the fish for each of them can be easily tested. At the end of the two week fishing trip the brothers each average out the weights of the fish they caught. Still keeping the amounts separate: We want one, accurate average for each brothers catch. A sample should be taken at random from the 150 screens (using a random sampling method such as a computerised random sampler), these would then be tested to see if they are good or bad. It is easier and faster to test a sample than the whole order of 150 screens. If more than 5% of the sample are bad, the company ought to reject the order in return for a refund. This is because we can assume that the sample is representative of the population and therefore it is likely that more than 5% of the total screens are bad.
Statistical inference can be used in this scenario since properties of a population are inferred from a sample.

You would get a random sample from the population you wish to test. These would then try to identify the notes played by the instructor. The number they get right would then be collected as data. One could expect this to form a normal distribution, with the majority being "average" and some being very good or very bad. Comparing the result to the normal distribution curve can then allow us to see if it is likely that they were simply guessing, or if they did "better than chance" in which case it could be argued that they have a good ear for music. This is done in the form of a p- value which would ideally be small to reject the null hypothesis (ie very unlikely that the student did so well when just guessing).
You should not use inferential statistics in this case since it does not use data from a sample to infer something about a larger population.

We take the percentage of bad bulks from the data gathered by the engineer.  /  / null hypothesis: the percentage of bad bulks in company's production is 5% / Alternative hypothesis: the percentage of bad bulks in company's production is more than 5% /  / We assume that the true percentage of bad bulks is 5%. We plug in the percentage we find from the sample into a normal distribution centered at 5% to find the percentage of values in the distribution that is as extreme or more extreme than the observed value. If the percentage is smaller than 5%, we can conclude that the percentage of bad bulks of the company's production is more than 5% (reject null), vice versa (fail reject null).

Yes. Because we assume that the 150 bulks is a representative sample of the entire production of bulks from the company. i.e. If there are more than 5% bad from the 150 bulks, it is likely that the company's production does not have good enough quality. However, there is a risk that it is possible that the sample does not represent the percentage of bad bulks as the population. The variance of the quality might be different among samples.

Let Carla try recognise the notes 20 times, and record the notes she recognizes each time. /  / Find the mean of the 20 trials /  / Find the percentage of the value that is as extreme or more extreme than the mean of Carla's performance (one-sided) in a normal distribution of random counts between 0 and 7 for thousand times. (should be a bell shaped distribution entered at 3.5) /  / The percentage is the p-value. If this value is smaller than 0.05, we can conclude that Carla has a good ear for music, not by random chance, vice versa. /  /
Yes. We can use statistical inference to decide whether Carla's performance is just "good" by chance or not.

1. Play the notes an X amount of times in a random order and record whether the student answers correct or incorrect.  / 2. Use a simulation to create a normal distribution. Hereby the chance of correct is 1/7 and the chance of incorrect is 6/7 / 3. Then calculate the proportion of successes of the student. number of successes divided by n. / 4. Count the values as extreme as and more extreme than the number of successes of the participants divided by n to calculate a p-value. / 5. When there is a p-value of 0.01 or less there is very strong evidence against the null, meaning that the student has a good ear for music. When the p-value is between 0.05 and 0.01 there is strong evidence against the null, and when the p-value is between 0.05 and 0.10 there is moderate evidence against the null. In all these cases the results are significant and cannot have been due to luck. Therefore, in these cases it can be concluded that the student has a good ear for music. However, when the p-value is larger than 0.10, there is little to no evidence against the null, meaning that the results could have been obtained by random guessing. Therefore, the null is then plausible and based on this test it cannot be concluded that the student has a good ear for music.

I propose to do an independent sample t-test. Mark and Dan are clearly two independent individuals and we would like to know whether the mean differences in size of fish they catch are significant.  / Firstly, the null hypothesis states that the mean fish size of fish caught by Mark is equal to the mean fish size of those caught by Dan. / The alternative hypothesis states that the mean fish sizes of Mark and Dan are not equal. The critical region has to be located by finding the degrees of freedom (=degrees of freedom first sample plus degrees of freedom second sample) and deciding on an alpha level (usually 0.05), then the critical value can be found in the t-distribution table. Then the pooled variance has to be found, this is computed by adding the sum of squares of the two samples, divided by the df of the two samples. Then the pooled variance can be used to compute the estimated standard error, which is the square root of the pooled variance over n1 (sample of Mark) plus the pooled variance over n2 (sample of Dan). To calculate the t-statistic, we substract the hypothesized difference (0) from the actual observed difference in means and divide this by the estimated standard error. If the t-statistic is larger than the critical t-value, we reject the null hypothesis.
Yes statistical inference should be used in this case, without statistical inference it would be impossible to tell whether the difference between Mark and Dan is significant or simply due to chance.

I propose that the method of note identification is done multiple times, so that a sample mean for the student can be calculated. Then we need to know the population mean, in order to see whether the student is significantly better than the average of the population. Lastly we need to know the standard error, which is calculated by dividing the population standard deviation over the square root of the sample size. / The null hypothesis states that the sample mean is equal to the population mean. / The alternative hypothesis states that the sample mean is higher than the population mean. The alternative hypothesis indicates that we are doing a one tailed test, we are only interested to see of the student is better than average. / We locate the critical z-value for an alpha of 0.10 (as it is a one tailed test). By looking at the z-distribution table we can find this value. / We calculate the z-statistic by calculating the difference between the sample mean and the population mean and dividing this by the standard error. If the z-statistic is larger than the critical value, we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that it is likely that this student has a good ear for music.

Yes it would by good to use statistical inference in this scenario, because by statistical inference one can differentiate between a result that could be achieved due to chance and a result that is significant (most likely not due to chance).

I would proceed with a two sample t test. /  / Given the recorded lengths for each fish collected by the two brothers, I will record the two means and create histograms of the distribution of length of the fishes for the two subjects.  / I expect to obtain from this two means, the respective standard deviations and sample size (which were not present in the text, of course). /  / Hypothesis to test are: / null - there is no difference between the average length of fishes caught by either of the two brothers / alternative - there is a difference /  / conditions to check for are: / - independence: were the two groups independent? was each measure collected independently? / - randomization (cannot be accounted for) / - Normality: were the distributions of means normal? (also depends on sample size) /  / if those conditions are met I can perform the t test and obtain a p value, telling me whether I should reject the null HP or not. if the null hypothesis is rejected, it may be significant to fully answer the question of who between the brothers caught the longest fishes by creating a confidence interval. /  /
I can make use of statistical inference as the problem entails a comparison of means, which can be easily tackled with a two sample t test.

Goodness of fit chi square test is the most appropriate statistical tool in this case. /  / Given my model of what would be a decent enough purchase for the company, I will compare the predicted values (how many screens are broken/how many are in good conditions) to the current order. /  / Does the distribution of counts for the new order respect my model? / The null hypothesis for my test is that yes, the new order fits the model. / The alternative is that it does not. /  / The company will reject those orders that yield a high chi square and a low p value, as in that case they will be dealing with a batch with more than 5% of broken screens.
Yes. I could fit a model accounting for 5% of damaged items and then check whether the observed case fits - if it exceeds, I reject.

If I had specific criteria concerning those who "have a good ear for music" I could constitute a model of how many times I would expect the subject to guess the note played correctly. / I would then test my model against the observed data. /  / This type of study would involve comparing counts, more specifically performing a chi square test for goodness of fit. / The amount of success would be a count, and I would test this distribution in Carla's case to the model of the "good ear for music". / To perform the chi square I should respect the conditions of: / - counted data / - independence  / - randomization / - cell frequency (which would mean repeating sufficient amount of times the experiment)

For this we would use matched pairs test.  You would take the differences of the average length of the Walleye caught and make your hypothesis test.  You then would check all the assumptions and conditions. If all are met you would follow the central  limit theorem.  You would draw out a normal model and find the standard error.  Once that's found you want to find the test statistic.  this will be your d bar subtract 0 over your standard error.  This you will place on the normal model and shade according to your hypothesis test.  This will be your p-value area.  The last step is to calculate your p-value using your calculator. You want to use the tcdf and enter the test statistic, then the upper or lower part of the normal model which ever way you shaded the region.  Then you want to enter the df value which is n-1.  This will allow you to either reject or fail to reject the null.
Yes you would use statistical inference with whether Mark or Dan is a better Walleye fisherman.

You would first start off by stating you hypothesis.  Then check your assumptions and conditions which are all met.  Then by the central limit theorem you can find the standard error.  On a normal model you can place your standard error and fine the area for you p-value.  Before the p-value you want to find your test statistic.  You would take you P hat and subtract your hypothesis test number and divide it by your standard error.  This gives you your z value which you can proceed finding the p-value using your normalcdf on your calculator.  With this value you can decide whether to reject or fail to reject the null.
You should use statistical inference in this scenario because it sets you up for an proportions z-hypothesis test from the information given.

As I said above I would use the probability method to figure out if Carla has a good ear for music. I would do about 5-10 trials to test her ability to have a good ear for music. Therefore, Carla would be asked 5-10 times what note the teacher was playing. This way it shows that Carla is not simply guessing and that she actually knows what she is doing. If you calculate the probability, or the likelihood, that Carla would get a note correctly you can see how gifted she is. For instance, if we test her only on 3 notes she has a higher probability of getting it right because she doesn't have that many options whereas if we were to test her on 10 different notes on the piano it would be harder for Carla to recognize all the different notes because there are more possible chances of her picking the wrong note and failing.

Yes, using probability can infer if Carla has a good ear for music. If Carla guesses wrong multiple times when she has a high probability of guessing the correct answer then you will know she has a bad ear for music. If Carla guesses right multiple times (examining her through multiple trials) when she has a low probability of guessing the correct answer you will know she has a good ear for music and that it is not just luck.

To determine wether Mark or Dan is a "better" fisherman, we will use a 2-Sample T-test. The null-hypothesis we would test is that the mean average length of Marks fish- the mean average of Dans fish will be 0. The alternative hypothesis would be that length of Marks fish - length of Dans fish would be greater the 0, and if this is proven it will show Mark catches "better" fish. If the null-hypothesis is not rejected, you can reverse the subtraction equation to do Dan - Mark, and this will test if Dan in fact caught better fish. If neither give a pvalue small enough to reject the null hypotheis, neither brother is better.
Yes statistical inference can be used to determine who is a "better" fisherman. It can be used because we are looking at the means of 2 independent groups, Mark and Dan.

Is Mark or Dan the better fisherman? / The study following this question would look at comparing the mean fish size for each man.  / First the null hypothesis would be that one is not better than the other, and that consequentially the difference between the means should equal 0. The alternative hypothesis would thus be that one is better than the other.  / To test this a null model should be made using a programme or by hand. The null model will show a normal curve with 0 being in the centre and with the most data in this area (The null hypothesized difference). Next the actual difference should be calculated, this should be done by taking away one vale (mean fish size of one man) from the other value. The difference between these two numbers should then be found on the null graph. Visually significance can be observed if the observed value is far out in the tails of the plot. This would suggest that with the data provided it is unlikely that the value would be 0. The further in the tail, the higher the significance and the lower the p-value. After finding the p-value it should be interpreted. If it is lower than 0.05 then at the 95% level, this would be considered significant.  / A Confidence interval can also be calculated. To do this, first the margin of error must be calculated by using this formula: Za/2 * /(n). Za/2 = the confidence coefficient, where a = confidence level,  = standard deviation, and n = sample size. The confidence interval can then be calculated by this formula: Mean +/- Margin if error. This will give the upper and lower bounds of the confidence interval. If the confidence interval includes 0, this suggests insignificance. Confidence intervals far from, and not including 0 suggest higher significance.
Yes, statistical inference could be used. The means should be compared.

Does Carla have an ear for music? / The study following this question would look at the rate that Carla is correct about the note she hears.  / However, as the student could learn during the test they will hear one note, give an answer and then listen to 5 minutes of white noise.  / First the null hypothesis would be that She has no ear for music. This could also be written as the number of times she gets the note right is the same as the number of times she gets it wrong, the difference being 0. The alternative would then be that she does have an ear for music and the difference between the times she gets it wrong and the times she gets it right are above 0 (right - wrong).  / To test this a null model should be made using a programme or by hand. The null model will show a normal curve with 0 being in the centre and with the most data in this area (The null hypothesized difference). Next the actual difference should be calculated, this should be done by first finding the difference between the number of times she gets it wrong and the times she gets it right. The difference should then be found on the null graph. Visually significance can be observed if the observed value is far out in the tails of the plot. This would suggest that with the data provided it is unlikely that the value would be 0. The further in the tail, the higher the significance and the lower the p-value. After finding the p-value it should be interpreted. If it is lower than 0.05 then at the 95% level, this would be considered significant.  / A Confidence interval can also be calculated. To do this, first the margin of error must be calculated by using this formula: Za/2 * /(n). Za/2 = the confidence coefficient, where a = confidence level,  = standard deviation, and n = sample size. The confidence interval can then be calculated by this formula: Mean +/- Margin if error. This will give the upper and lower bounds of the confidence interval. If the confidence interval includes 0, this suggests insignificance. Confidence intervals far from, and not including 0 suggest higher significance.

A two sample t-test for the difference between two means should be used in this scenario in order to find out which of the two brothers is better at Walleye fish fishing during their trip.  /  / First the student should establish the plan just as above, then he/she would need to formulate the null and alternative hypothesis /  / These should be as follows: / null hypothesis: the difference in caught fish size equals to zero   / alternative hypothesis: the difference in caught fish size does not equal to zero /  / Then assumptions and conditions should be considered. These are as follows: randomized condition, independence assumption, independent group assumption and finally the nearly normal condition.  /  / At the end of the trip, the two brothers should compute the data concerning the length of each fish that they have caught in order to come up with individual means that will then be compared.  /  / They should come up with histogram which will assist them in analyze their data and making them more easy to read. /  / Once all the steps above have been achieved, the student can run the two sample t- test in order to find the p- value which will allow the student to check whether or not he/she should reject or accept the null hypothesis. In case that the p-value is less than 0.05, the null hypothesis should be rejected

In order to determine whether there was a difference between the average lenght of the fishes caught by either brother, one would have to determine the mean and standard error for both sets of fishes first. After the means and standard errors are determined one has to find the corresponding t-value in order to perform a two-sample t-test, which can be used to find a P-value for the null hypothesis (which usually states that there was no difference between both groups) If the P-value is low enough the null hypothesis can be rejected, otherwise one fails to reject it.

Statistical inference can be used in this case since two different groups of data exist, which can be compared with one another. The lenght of the fishes that are caught by the two different brothers can be averaged and compared, yet it is not clear whether the two datasets are independent of one another since they were fishing in the same area and one cannot be sure whether the fishing itself has an effect on further fishing.

This is the step by step process I would use to see if a student has a good ear for music. /  / 1) I would start with a control comparison. I would have famous musicians, music teachers, and other successful musicians and have them stand facing away from the piano. Then I would have them identify 50 randomly selected notes. It would be important to get a big enough sample of participants, in order to later create a normal model. /  / 2) I would take their percentages, and find the mean (using the mean formula) and the standard deviation (using the standard deviation formula) /  / 3) Now I would ask the student to stand facing away from the piano and identify 50 random notes.  /  / 4) I would calculate the percentage of notes correct, and find the z-score based on the previous "famous musician" scale /  / 5) If the student received the mean or higher on this scale, I would assume he or she had a good ear for music

The test would be: /  / Stating assumptions: /  / (1) Sample is a simple random sample, no outliers, and state whether or not you will do a t or z test. T-test is always safe.  /  / Define paramaters being estimated: /  / (2)  Population mean, in context /  / State null hypothesis: /  / (3) State that =the sample mean to indicate no change /  / State alternative hypothesis: /  / (4) Different than the null hypothesis, in this case =/=your temporary value for  /  / Carry out t test. /  / Analyze the data. Low p-value indicates that it is unlikely that the population mean is the sample mean which would indicate that the results could not be used to compare against Carla's. A higher p-value would indicate the opposite. /  / If the p-value is a high enough value, then Carla's results could be compared to the working population mean. Before testing a student I would determine the percentage out of ten notes that the student must correctly identify to be considered a student with an "ear for music". I would set this at 0.80 and an alpha level of 0.10. As stated in the background information, I would have the student face away from the piano and make sure there is no reflective surfaces around them. I would have the teacher play a random note on the piano and allow the student 15 seconds to respond before the next note is played.  I would have the test consist of this one note, wait 15 second process for ten notes.  Then I would have the student wait for an hour and then have the student return and do the test again.  I would have the student to the test 5 times in total.  With the data from the tests recorded I would determine the average number of notes identified correctly per test and make a distribution of the results.  I would then do a hypothesis test to determine if there was a significant evidence that they do indeed have an "ear for music". I would have a null and alternative hypothesis (alternative= greater than 0.8).  I would then determine that the distribution fits a normal model by checking the conditions. Find the test statistic and the p-value and determine if there is enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis.

For a hypothesis test, you first need to determine your population, sample, parameter, and statistic.  /  / From there you can create your null (Ho:p=.05) and alt (Ha: p>.05) hypotheses.  /  / Next you have to check your conditions: Randomization, 10%, and Success/Failure Conditions /  / From there, you need to determine if your sampling distribution will follow the normal model if the null hypothesis is true. /  / Then you need to find your test statistic or z*: z=p^-po /                                                                             ------------- /                                                                            sq.rt: po (1-po)/ n /  / You then look up your test statistic in the ztable to find your p-value. You will use the Alt hypothesis to determine if you need to look at the lower in of the tail, the higher end of the tail, or both sides of the tail of the bell curve to determine the p-value. (ex: in this problem, you would look at the higher end, therefore you would subtract your z value from 1 to obtain your final p-value.  /  / You then compare your p-value to alpha and decide whether to accept or reject the null hypothesis.  /  / Finally, you make your conclusion and make sure to incorporate your decision, the parameter, the context, and whether or not there is enough evidence for the alternative hypothesis.

Yes, there is enough information present in the problem to create a hypothesis test using the null and alternative hypotheses to determine whether or not the company should accept the display screens. You would use this 150 as one sample to create your problem and make a hypothesis about the true proportion of bad screens--> which you could then decide if you should even continue to use this company at all.

You could suggest a hypothesis that a certain percentage of students (ex:33%) would pass this method test of having a "good ear for music". You could then ask the question is there enough evidence to suggest that the population of students who have a good ear for music is more than 33%. /  / You could then suggest a Null hypothesis and Alternative hypothesis due to the percentage of students, the sample size, and the overall student population. /  / To do this you would need to determine your population, sample, parameter, and statistic. /  / Next, you state your Null and Alt Hypothesis. (ex: Ho: p=.33 and Ha: p>.33) /  / After, you need to check your conditions (Randomization, 10%, and Success/Failure Conditions) /  / If all of your conditions pass, you can determine your sampling distribution if the Null hypothesis is true, which should follow a normal distribution. /  / You can then find your test statistic (z-score) following the z formula: z=p^-po /                                                                                                              -------------- /                                                                                                              sq.rt: po(1-po)/n /  / You then look up your z-score in the z table to find your p-value. To do this you need to determine if the alternative hypothesis is <,>, or not =. You then follow the graph and sign of the alternative hypothesis to determine if you need to subtract from 1, or just find the value in the table. /  / This gives your p-value which you need to compare to alpha. *It is VERY important to set your alpha value before you dive into the process of solving for the p-value* If your p-value is less than alpha, you have enough evidence to reject the null, and if the p-value is greater than alpha, there is not enough evidence so you fail to reject the null. /  / After comparing to alpha, make the decision to either reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis. /  / Finally, bring it back into context and make an overall conclusion including your decision, whether or not there is enough evidence, the parameter, and how it relates back to the null hypothesis /

Conduct a One sample Hypothesis test to see if the students have a good ear for music. /  / 1.  State assumptions:  / We would have to assume that the sample of students is an srs and has no outliers and is aprox normal. /  / We conduct a z-test or t-test based on how large the sample is  /  / 2. define the parameters: / Mean # of students in a music class with a good ear for music /  / 3. state hypotheses: / Ho: the students in the sample have a mean that is equal to that of the population mean / Ha: the students in the sample have a mean that is greater than the population's mean  /  / 4. carry out a z-test or a t-test / chosen based on how large the sample is. /  / 5. interpret the p-value you end up with. reject or accept the null hypothesis, and identify error if there is one. /  /

To determine if the screens should be sent back or not, you need to conduct a hypothesis test. Start by identifying the population, sample, parameter, and statistic in the problem. Next, determine your null hypothesis and alternative hypothesis. The null hypothesis is the value the parameter is assumed to be and the alternative hypothesis is the claim about the parameter that you would like to find evidence for. In this case, the null hypothesis would be p=0.05 and the alternative hypothesis would be p>0.05. Next, test to see if all of the conditions/assumptions are met. These include the randomization, 10%, and nearly normal population distribution conditions. If these conditions are met, continue on to do the test statistic. If the null hypothesis is true, the t-test statistic will follow a t distribution with n-1 degrees of freedom. After finding the t-test statistic, determine the p-value. If this p-value is greater than the significance value (alpha), then you fail to reject the null hypothesis and you would not have enough evidence to reject the screens. If the p-value is less than the significance value (alpha), then you reject the null hypothesis and you would have enough evidence to reject the screens.
Yes, statistical inference could be used to determine this because conducting a hypothesis test would allow them to determine if the more than 5% of the screens are bad.

The brothers should have similarly large samples of fishes from the day of comparison. Then I would measure the length of each fish from each brother and calculate the mean average fish length for each brother. Then I would run a two-sample t-test for differences between means ( on SPSS or applet). If the p-value I obtained from this t-test was lower than 0.05, I would reject my null hypothesis and say that it is likely that one brother is a better fisherman (based on lenths of the fishes) as the results were unlikely to occur by chance alone.  / To do such a t-test in SPSS, I would click "analyse", "compare means", "independent samples t-test" and add the two quantitaive variables "meanLengthDan" and "meanLengthMark".

I would let the notes be played randomly by the teacher a large number of times. Say 10 times per note, leading to a total sample of 70 notes that Carla has to identify. Then I would note down for each of this 70 times, whether her decision was "correct" or "false". If Carla was just guessing, she should have a "correct" rate of about 14.28 %. I would use this number as the null hypothesis. Meaning that if the null hypothesis is true and Carla was just guessing, then the statistic x-bar is expected to be not significantly higher than 14.28%. Then I would use an applet (which we used in our statistics class) and simulate the experiment 1000 times to obtain a null distribution. Then I would test a one-sided hypothesis, because we want to know whether Carla has a good ear for music. So I would but in the statistic x-bar I got from the 70 trials with Carla and add it to the simulation distribution. I would then obtain a simulated p-value. If this p-value is lower than 0.05, I would reject my null hypothesis, as this p-value would provide evidence that it is likely that Carla does have a "good ear for music".  / Alternatively, with a sample size this large, a t-model would be appropriate as well to obtain a modelled p-value.

We want to compare two means, namely the fish lengths of both brothers. The samples of both brothers are independent: because they fish in different places, it is rather unlikely that the length of the fish Mark catches affects the length of the fish Dan catches. Thus, the appropriate study design is an independent two samples t-test.  /  / Firstly, we compute the means and standard deviations for both samples. Now we subtract the means from one another, and subtract from this number the difference in fish lengths we would expect if the brothers were equally good fishers: 0. Subsequently, we divide this number by the standard error. We find the standard error by summing up standard deviation Mark/sample size Mark + standard deviation Dan/sample size Dan, and taking the square root of that whole.  /  / What we find is, again, a t-statistic. This t-statistic tells us how likely it is, assuming that both brothers are equally good fishers, that there would be such a difference in their mean fish lengths. A large t-statistic tells us it is very unlikely that this difference would occur, and that probably one of the brothers is a more skilled fisher. A small t-statistic tells us that even if the brothers are equally good fishers, the observed difference in fish length is not unlikely to occur just by random chance. That is, we may believe that of all the Walleyes both could potentially fish, one accidentally happened to catch more of the large ones and the other accidentally more of the small ones.

Statistical inference should be used, because both brothers catch only a sample of all the Walleye fish they could potentially catch: the population. We estimate their average fish length on the basis of the length of the fish they really catch, but what we really want to know is if both would catch all Walleye fish they could potentially catch, who would have the higher average length. In order to compare their mean fish lengths, we use statistical inference.

The engineer has to count the defect screens and divide the count by 150. If the outcome is greater than 0.05 he rejects the bulk order, if it is smaller than 0.05 he accepts it. The engineer may only reject orders if more than 5% of the screens are bad. Thus, he must count the defect screens for every order and may not rely on an average percentage of defect screens in bulk orders to turn a bulk order down.

Statistical inference is not necessary here. The engineer wants to know for each bulk whether more or less than 5%  of the screens are bad. Thus, he will investigate each bulk to draw his conclusion for that particular bulk, rather than testing hypothesis to make estimates for the population of bulk orders.

The null hypothesis is that Carla guesses right 1/7th of the time.  / The alternative hypothesis is that Carla guesses right more than 1/7th of the time. /  / After repeating the experiment many times, we have a proportion of observed correct guesses. This proportion will most likely deviate to some extent from the expected proportion 1/7th. However, does this deviation constitute statistical evidence against the null hypothesis that Carla is just guessing and will in the long run get 1/7th of the guesses correct? /  / In order to assess this we perform a simple z-test. We subtract the expected proportion 1/7th from the observed proportion, and divide by the standard deviation of the expected proportion. This standard error is computed by multiplying expected proportion with 1-expected proportion, dividing by the sample size, and taking the square root of that whole. The outcome of this calculation is a z-score.  /  / The z-score indicates how likely it is that an observed proportion would deviate to the extent that it does from the expected proportion. If z is large, that means the deviation is very unlikely to occur just by random chance: if Carla scores 6/7 correct the z-score will be large, and we will be inclined to believe that she really has a good ear for music. If z is small, for example if Carla scores 3/14 correct, we may still believe she is just guessing, but by random chance has guessed right slightly more often than we would expect her to.

Yes, you should use statistical inference. If Carla is just guessing randomly for the notes, we would expect her to guess right approximately 1/7th of the time in the long run. This would be the null hypothesis. From the discrepancy between the expected proportion of correct guesses and the real proportion of correct guesses we infer estimates about the quality of Carla's good ear for music.

sample the first 10 displays from 10 different bulks.  / calculate an average of bad displays in those 10 different bulks. / Use this data to create a Maximum Likelihood Estimator (p=x/n) to estimate a parameter for all possible values of an average of bad displays in a bulk. / Use your MLE value to create a 90% Confidence Interval which will eliminate the top 5% and bottom 5% of average values to show an interval in which we can be 90% confident that an average of bad displays would fall into. / Use this interval for every bulk (after the first 10). If the first 10 displays from each bulk has an average of bad displays within this interval, accept the bulk. If the average lies above the interval, reject the bulk. /  /

Yes, statistical inference should be used to a) save time and allow the engineer to not have to individually test each display separately and, b) ensure that the bulks that are accepted will have no more than 5% of the displays be bad.

So the engineer took the 150 displays as the sample and observes that 5 of these are defective. Based on these results, the engineer computes the statistic, 5/150 = 0.03, as an estimate of the parameter p , or true proportion of defective items in the entire population. Based  on the percentage of defects for the entire population being low and less than the 5%, the recommendation would be to accept the entire batch.  That 5% defect standard is a great measurement to determine if the entire batch should be returned.  /

Statistical inference is often use for this type of inventory for goods as well as data from specific sources.  The use of randomization supports using the methods of statistical inference. The reality of this is that all the screens can not be reviewed.  Therefore the engineer infer conclusions about a given population based on results observed through random sampling.  Statistical inference is needed.

You will create a null hypothesis and alternative hypothesis.  / Ho: u= Both Mark and Dan's mean length in fish were the same. / Ha: u(not equal)= Mark and Dan's mean length in fish were different. / Using statcrunch, make two columns.  One for Mark and one for Dan.  Under their names, record the lengths of each fish they caught. / Go to stat, nonparmentrics, Mann-Whitney, with data, select both columns, and compute.  You will then get a p-value.  If the p-value is less than .05, then you will reject the null hypothesis and can conclude that there in enough evidence to support that Mark and Dan did not catch the same length of fish.  If the p-value is above .05, then you will fail to reject and there is not enough evidence to conclude that they caught different lengths of fish.

You will create a null hypothesis and alternative hypothesis.  / Ho: p= 150 / Ha: p(not equal)= 150 / You would use statcrunch to find the answer.   / You would go to stat, proportion stat, with summary, and plug in your obersved and success rate.  Also select the 95% interval.  / There you will recive a P-value.  If the p-value is less than .05 then you will not reject the null hypothesis and you can conclude that all screens can be used.  If the p-value is above .05, then you will fail to reject and there is not enough evidence to conclude that they can use the screens.
